questions.question: What is the primary purpose of converting a Context-Free Grammar (CFG) to Chomsky Normal Form (CNF)?

answers.a: To simplify the grammar and facilitate analysis.
answers.c: To introduce ambiguity in language structure.

explanations.a: Converting CFG to CNF simplifies the grammar for easier analysis. [Learn more](www.examplelink.com).
explanations.b: While CNF simplifies the grammar, it does not aim to increase expressiveness or flexibility.
explanations.c: Converting to CNF aims to reduce ambiguity in language structure.
explanations.d: CNF primarily focuses on structural simplification, not lexical analysis.

questions.question: In the context of Context-Free Grammar (CFG) conversion, what does GNF stand for?

explanations.a: Incorrect. GNF stands for Greibach Normal Form.
explanations.b: Correct! GNF stands for Greibach Normal Form, a specific form of CFG.
explanations.c: Incorrect. GNF does not stand for Graphical Normal Form.
explanations.d: Incorrect. GNF stands for Greibach Normal Form, not Grouped Nonterminal Form.

questions.question: Why might a linguist or a compiler designer choose to convert a CFG to Greibach Normal Form (GNF)?

answers.a: To enhance human readability of the grammar.
answers.b: To conform to a specific standard or convention.
answers.c: To increase ambiguity in language interpretation.
answers.d: To simplify the grammar for compiler optimization.

explanations.a: GNF is not primarily chosen for enhancing human readability.
explanations.b: Correct! Converting to GNF may be done to adhere to a specific standard or convention in language representation.
explanations.c: Converting to GNF aims to reduce ambiguity, not increase it.
explanations.d: Simplifying the grammar for compiler optimization is a valid reason for choosing GNF.
